Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences in Physiology and Neurobiology at UCONN
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the University of Connecticut, located in Storrs, CT, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2016-2018. The Department of Physiology and Neurobiology (PNB) will offer research opportunities to undergraduate sophomores and juniors from non-Ph.D. granting institutions. The students will participate in graduate level research projects on physiological and neural systems in animals. The goal is to expose students to a career in scientific research, and to increase student applications to graduate programs in basic science. Students are selected on the basis of their academic record, personal and professional goals described in a required essay, and letters of recommendation. Interested students, especially underrepresented minorities, veterans, first-generation college students, and students with disabilities from institutions with limited research opportunities are encouraged to apply. REU students will be part of a campus multidisciplinary REU community consisting of several programs in the physical sciences and engineering as well as physiology and neurobiology. Students are housed together, and work with faculty mentors on their own research project. Professional development and cohort-building activities are planned. Seminars introduce students to topics such as safe practices in the laboratories, ethical issues in science, how to apply to graduate school, and how to present research results effectively. An end-of-program symposium features student platform talks and poster presentations.

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program. Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine student career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://www.pnb.uconn.edu/research-experience-for-undergraduates-reu-program/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Xinnian Chen at xinnian.chen@uconn.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Larry Renfro at larry.renfro@uconn.edu)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Our REU program has been providing independent research experiences, rich academic training, and social support to our undergraduate researchers for the last 12 years. In this grant cycle, the goals of our program have all been met. The major objectives were to provide undergraduates from diverse and primarily non-Ph.D. granting institutions with immersion in a collegial atmosphere and stimulating research laboratory and to nurture interest in a scientific career.  Over the past three summers we brought a total of 30 students through the program. 

Exceeding our target (50%) of participation by students from disadvantaged backgrounds, 70% of REU students were URMs and almost 90% were from non-PhD granting institutions.  In addition, three students (10%) with disabilities participated during this grant cycle.  

Programmatic activities include workshops, panels, and tours that help to improve students' communication and scientific skills and build knowledge about graduate school and a typical application process. Starting this grant cycle, we have also added some new components to further strengthen participants' broader communication skills, such as vlogging for the public. 

Overall, post-program surveys and interviews, follow-up emails strongly indicate that students gain an appreciation for and understanding of the life of a research scientist as a result of the PNB REU program.  A majority of those who continue on to become PhD students express the conviction that our program was instrumental in their decision to attend graduate school.  

Two REU students from this grant cycle were able to contribute to two peer-reviewed journal articles. To this date, UConn PNB REU site has produced eight peer-reviewed journal articles.

Broader Impact:

Over this grant cycle, 30 students with limited research opportunities, underrepresented minority students, and students with disabilities were able to be exposed to life in the research lab, where they learned how to work as a member of a collaborative research team, perform cutting-edge techniques, and formulate their own research questions and an approach to answer them. Many previous REU students reported "a great deal of ownership over my REU project". Some have even reported discovering a true passion about research. REU participants honed skills, gained confidence, developed a sense of belonging in the science community, and established networks with peers from a range of disciplines and experiences. The program opens the possibility of a scientific research career to students who may otherwise not have the opportunity to explore such an option first-hand. For example, five out of ten students that participated in 2016 REU program are now enrolled in PhD programs in NSF-related fields. Many current PhD students spontaneously cited this program as instrumental in their decision to attend and success in graduate school. Furthermore, their participation in social and educational activities with an ethnically diverse group of summer research students has better prepared them to work in, and contribute to, a multicultural world. Their research project outcomes, and overall experience in the program, were disseminated to a boarder audience in a variety of different ways including vlogs, poster symposia, and podium presentations.
